review.title: How to advance general game playing artificial intelligence by player modelling
review.abstract: General game playing artificial intelligence has recently seen important advances due to the various techniques known as 'deep learning'. However the advances conceal equally important limitations in their reliance on: massive data sets; fortuitously constructed problems; and absence of any human-level complexity, including other human opponents. On the other hand, deep learning systems which do beat human champions, such as in Go, do not generalise well. The power of deep learning simultaneously exposes its weakness. Given that deep learning is mostly clever reconfigurations of well-established methods, moving beyond the state of art calls for forward-thinking visionary solutions, not just more of the same. I present the argument that general game playing artificial intelligence will require a generalised player model. This is because games are inherently human artefacts which therefore, as a class of problems, contain cases which require a human-style problem solving approach. I relate this argument to the performance of state of art general game playing agents. I then describe a concept for a formal category theoretic basis to a generalised player model. This formal model approach integrates my existing 'Behavlets' method for psychologically-derived player modelling:

sections.heading: A. Behavlets
sections.text: A general model should provide insight into various facets of the player's behavior, for example, the cognitive information processing style of a player. It therefore requires a foundation of parameters that describe the subjective experience of the game. It will draw on established modeling tools, including at least: i) behavioral psychology; ii) general game design; and iii) actions in the context of a given game. I have already proposed the Behavlet Method [7] to incorporate facets i) to iii) above into composite features of the game that are defined across entire action sequences. The goal is to create features of the player model that are associated with valid psychological theory. The Behavlet Process integrates descriptive models for temperament theory, game design patterns, and patterns of player actions. The core concept is to capture behaviors with a certain known personality bias, such as aggression, caution, and thus observe the player's self-expression.

Note that the games can be ordered in a mathematical system because they are based on rule-based interactions, and that the mechanisms of the game essentially look as if they are following the rules.

sections.heading: C. Summary
sections.text: In this essay, I intend to provide a notation to present behaviors as action sequences in a formally defined simulation of a game system by extension [11]. The motivation is to create a representation of possible player actions and the archetypal behavioral traits that can shape these actions so that representation can be used as input for a learning system. Ultimately, the goal is to learn from real human behavior. Later in the essay, I will first give a brief literature review in the next section. In Section III, I will describe a formal model of a game system, before briefly showing in Section V how it can be used to represent some behaviors from [7]. Finally, in Section VI, I will suggest some future directions of work.

sections.heading: IV. BEHAVLETS-BASED FORMAL MODEL
sections.text: As already mentioned, the intention is to formalize the behavilet method of player modeling. As stated in the formal model definition, this can be done by using orbits to represent the game patterns that occur in the game. Here, I describe this idea. To select this game pattern, one essentially has to select a game pattern associated with a temperament trait. Therefore, a well-chosen monoid representation of a pattern that corresponds to the behavilet logic defined in [7] is also a behavilet start state (q, x0) i equivalent to the behavilet concept of limited hardness defined in [7].An example illustrates the approach for which I am already peer-reviewed [9] and empirically tested.

sections.heading: V. DISCUSSION
sections.text: The approach I have described for a generalized player model relies on the behavioral method to create psychologically grounded characteristics of the game and redefines them as parts of a formal category theory model. The value of this approach is that behavioral models of certain games can be further generalized under a formal framework through the use of simulations.

sections.heading: A. Potential applications
sections.text: The primary use case for the described method is to record the variation of the player. Consider that if we model behaviors as elements of the game ΦX, then through the Behavlets method [7], each ΦX i will have a related behavioral trait. Thus, a game instance with a certain component of the game style can reflect the "character" of a particular player. Potentially, characteristics of the human game can be learned through enough such instances. It should also be noted that the method allows for abstraction and specificity: we can build a canonical game model and also simulate game instances quite simply from the same definitions, which allows the exploration of the space of possible game elements. This could be called personality profiling, but skill and strategy are also relevant considerations. Based on the work of [5], where the human being achieves near optimal solutions to hard problems, we can expect that the human skills provide the seeds for improved computer-based solutions.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION
sections.text: I argue that in order to promote general artificial intelligence play, it is necessary to include the player's perspective, since games are ultimately human artifacts and therefore contain cases that benefit from a human-style problem-solving approach, which implies the creation of a general player model. I have outlined a method for this based on integrating my previously published behaviors [7] with a formal game model, resulting in a vision for a general player model, not a complete and conclusive work that I hope will serve as an inspiration.
